name: Worker
uniques: Comment ['Reliable, replaceable, and remarkably flammable. No empire rose without them — mostly because someone had to hold the shovel. Can be upgrade into military unit']
Limited to [5] per Civilization <during the [Archaic Age]>
Limited to [8] per Civilization <during the [Classical Age]>
Limited to [12] per Civilization <during the [Imperial Age]>
Can upgrade to [Skirmisher] <after discovering [Imperial Military Doctrine]> <hidden from users>
Can upgrade to [Spearman] <after adopting [Citizen Militias]> <hidden from users>
Can upgrade to [Spearman] <after adopting [Divide Consription]> <hidden from users>
Can upgrade to [Spearman] <after adopting [Imperial Garrisons]> <hidden from users>
Can upgrade to [Swordsman] <after adopting [Total War]> <hidden from users>

name: Settler
uniques: Comment ['Men, women, and children — good at founding empires, great at dying for them']
Founds a new city <by consuming this unit>
Excess Food converted to Production when under construction
Unbuildable <in cities with a [Scenario]> <hidden from users>

name: Work Boats
uniques: May create improvements on water resources

name: Battering Ram
uniques: Comment ['Turns “no entry” into “former entry.” Teamwork highly encouraged.']
[30]% Strength bonus for [Melee] units within [0] tiles <when attacking> <vs cities>

name: Siege Tower
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Siege Workshop]>
Comment ['A revolutionary invention that made invading cities slightly less suicidal. Offers protection for your battle buddies while they commit structural diplomacy.']
[20]% Strength bonus for [Melee] units within [1] tiles <vs cities>
[10]% Strength bonus for [Melee] units within [1] tiles <when defending> <vs [Ranged] units>

name: Skirmisher
uniques: Comment ['Light troops trained to throw things and run away, in that order. The smart ones mastered both arts equally.']

civilopediaText.text: Light troops trained in the noble art of throwing things and running away. Skirmishers excel at harassing enemies, avoiding death, and reminding heavier soldiers why mobility matters. Historians call them “hit-and-run specialists.” The enemy just calls them cowards — usually right before getting another javelin in the face.

name: Thracian Peltast
uniques: Comment ['Thracian hit-and-run specialists; throw, stab, vanish, repeat.']

civilopediaText.text: Light skirmishers famed for their speed and deadly precision. The Thracians turned javelin warfare into an art — quick to strike, quicker to disappear. Greek generals called them “irregulars.” Everyone else called them gone.

name: Anatolian Tribesman
uniques: Comment ['Light tribal infantry from Anatolia — armed with courage, sticks, and whatever gods didn’t abandon them this week.']

civilopediaText.text: The Anatolian tribesman trusts no banner. Empires burn, mountains don’t.

name: Illyrian Raider
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Mercenary Camp]>
Comment ['Mercenary skirmisher from the Illyrian coast — fights hard, drinks harder, runs fastest when unpaid.']
Can be purchased with [Gold] [in all cities]

civilopediaText.text: The Illyrians were called pirates by the Greeks, “privateers” by the Romans, and “naval contractors” by themselves. History calls that good marketing.

name: Cilician Pirate
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Mercenary Camp]>
Comment ['Coastal skirmisher — hits hard, runs faster, drowns slower. Great at ranged attacks, terrible at staying for melee consequences.']
Can be purchased with [Gold] [in all cities]

civilopediaText.text: The Cilician pirates made the Mediterranean their playground, striking trade routes and vanishing before anyone could fight back. Fast ships, faster feet, and no sense of shame — the perfect combination for a long criminal career.

name: Archer
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Archery Range]>
Comment ['Light archer, ruins ambushes, morale, and anyone who forgot to bring a shield.']

civilopediaText.text: Archers changed warfare by proving you didn’t need armor to win — just range and fear management. From the ancient steppes to city walls, they fought with distance, discipline, and a deep respect for running away when charged.

name: Slinger
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Archery Range]>
Comment ['Light slinger, good at countering ranged units, because nothing says “primitive” like a rock to the face.']

civilopediaText.text: Ancient commanders loved slingers: they could kill from afar, cost next to nothing, and made archers nervous. That’s what we call “cost-effective terror.

name: Mysian Bowman
uniques: Comment ['Elite light archer, good at counter-ambushes, accuracy so good it feels personal.']
Only available <in cities with a [Archery Range]>

civilopediaText.text: The Mysians of Asia Minor gained fame as mercenary archers, hired across the Hellenistic world for their precision and willingness to actually hit what they aimed at. Pergamon turned their local talent into a professional corps — loyal, lethal, and occasionally sober.

name: Mardian Archer
uniques: Comment ['Elite light archer, not built for defense, built to make sure you don’t need any.']
Only available <in cities with a [Archery Range]>

civilopediaText.text: The Mardians of Persia served the Arsacid kings as elite archers, famed for their precision and unnerving enthusiasm for lethal accuracy. Lightly armored but heavily motivated, they hit hard and vanished before anyone could argue about it.

name: Forester Warband
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Archery Range]>
Comment ['Light Belgae archer, good at ambushing, bad at staying where you can see them.']

civilopediaText.text: The Belgae’s foresters knew every root and shadow of their homeland. In battle, they used the woods as both shield and trap, striking unseen and retreating before the enemy knew who fired. Rome called them barbarians; the trees called them locals.

name: Balearic Slinger
uniques: Comment ['Light slinger unit, known for turning iron and spite into long-range diplomacy.']
Only available <in cities with a [Archery Range]>

civilopediaText.text: The Balearic slingers earned their reputation long before Carthage made it official. Trained from childhood to hurl stones and iron darts with surgical precision, they served across the Mediterranean — loyal to coin, not causes.

name: Rhodian Slinger
uniques: Comment ['Rhodian mercenary — precise, portable, and politically unpredictable.']
Only available <in cities with a [Mercenary Camp]>
Can be purchased with [Gold] [in all cities]

name: Cretan Archer
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Mercenary Camp]>
Comment ['Veteran mercenary archer, fast, accurate, and morally flexible.']
Can be purchased with [Gold] [in all cities]
Never appears as a Barbarian unit

name: Mercenary Warband
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Mercenary Camp]>
Comment ['Medium shock infantry, proof that capitalism and violence can coexist beautifully.']
Can be purchased with [Gold] [in all cities]

name: Mercenary Axeman
uniques: Only available <in cities with a [Mercenary Camp]>

name: Spearman

Comment ['Spearman — ideal for stopping horses, not much else.']

name: Ligurian Warrior

name: Noble Hoplite

name: Swordsman

uniques: Comment ['Medium infantry, strong attack, limited patience.']

name: Gaesatae
uniques: Comment ['Light shock unit, excellent versus swords and spears, allergic to armor.']

name: Thracian Warband
uniques: Comment ['Medium infantry, hits hard, moves fast, and hates horses personally.']

name: Falxman

uniques: Comment [Light shock infantry, quick to raid, quick to die. Use them for the sneak attack, then pray they don’t get caught in the crossfire.]

civilopediaText.text: This is your basic, club-swinging fighter.

name: Legion
uniques: Comment [Heavy infantry, these guys can siege a city and build a highway at the same time. Too bad they’re slower than your grandma’s morning walk.]

Can build [Roman Fort] improvements on tiles

uniques: Comment [Light cavalry that’s great for hitting and running—because why fight when you can just annoy people and leave]

name: Camel Archer
uniques: Comment [Medium mounted archer, perfect for desert battles, as long as you don’t expect them to do anything when they leave the sand. They’ll shoot a few arrows and bail before you can blink.]

name: Chariot Archer
uniques: Comment [Medium ranged chariot, a chariot with a bow—because running around in circles is the best way to fight. Good in the desert, terrible on rough terrain. Expect them to get stuck faster than your last bad decision.]
